content.body: Let me see if I've got this straight...
Symbols can be put into 3 categories:
- Symbols created by the Symbol constructor

Symbols created by the Symbol constructor have language identity, the others don't. So Symbols created by Symbol() are suitable for use as a weak reference, and the others aren't, *except* that well-known symbols are.
content.formatted_body: Symbols created by the Symbol constructor have language identity, the others don't. So Symbols created by Symbol() are suitable for use as a weak reference, and the others aren't, except that well-known symbols are.

content.body: So in the one place that the spec uses the concept of 'language identity' (in the Note for CanBeHeldWeakly), it isn't even exactly the necessary concept.
(Actually, the 'Identity' section implies that well-known symbols *have* language identity, but I don't see how that could be. E.g., you can manifest @@match just by saying `Symbol.match`.)
content.formatted_body: (Actually, the 'Identity' section implies that well-known symbols have language identity, but I don't see how that could be. E.g., you can manifest @@match just by saying Symbol.match.)
